Effects of ultrasonic vibration on the microstructure and tensile properties of the
nano ZrB2/2024Al composites synthesized by direct melt reaction
Xizhou Kai, Kangle Tian, Chunmei Wang, Lei Jiao, Gang Chen, Yutao Zhao*
School of Material Science and Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang 212013, China
Abstract: In this study, the effects of high-energy ultrasonic vibration on the dispersion of in situ nano-sized reinforcements were studied in nano ZrB2 particle reinforced 2024Al matrix composites synthesized from 2024Al-K2ZrF6-KBF4 system by direct melt reaction. And the microstructure of the final composites treated with different processing time of ultrasonic vibration during fabrication was examined by XRD, SEM, EDS, TEM and the tensile properties of the fabricated composites were also tested. The results show that the introduction of high-energy ultrasonic vibration in the composite melts could break up the clusters of agglomerated in situ nano ZrB2, degas the melts, significantly and results in enhancement in mechanical properties of the final composites. And the optimized processing time for the fabrication of the nano ZrB2/2024Al composites was established via the microstructure observation of the final composites to be 5 min with 1.2 kW in power and 20 kHz in frequency. Meanwhile, the mechanisms of the high-intensity ultrasonic vibration on the improvement of the in situ nanoparticle distribution and tensile properties of the composites were also discussed. Keywords: High-energy ultrasonic; Aluminum matrix nanocomposites; ZrB2; Clustering; Porosity; Tensile properties

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Particle reinforced aluminum matrix composites have attracted widespread attentions in
aerospace, automobile and electronic areas, due to their specific characteristics, such as low density, high specific stiffness, high specific strength, good thermal stability, good wear resistance and economic viability [1-4]. And among the manufacturing techniques, the melt in situ reaction fabrication has been regarded as a prospective method for commercial production of Al matrix composites, due to its low cost and high efficiency [5-7]. Therefore, in the last 20 years, the in situ aluminum matrix composites have been subjected to great attentions. Tjong et al. studied the systems of Ti-Al-B, TiO2-Al-B and TiO2-Al-B2O3, respectively, and found that the equiaxed Al2O3 and TiB2 particulates with a size of less than 2 µm were in situ formed in the corresponding TiO2-Al-B and TiO2-Al-B2O3 systems [5]. Zhao and Kai et al. fabricated (Al2O3+Al3Zr)/Al composites and nano ZrB2/2024Al composites via the direct melt reaction from Al-Zr(CO3)2 system and 2024Al-K2ZrF6-KBF4 system, respectively [6, 8]. However, with the size decrease of the reinforcement, the clustering of the in situ synthesized particles has become an important issue in the fabrication of the in situ particle reinforced aluminum matrix composites by conventional stir casting techniques, which limits the further improvement of their mechanical properties. In order to solve this problem, some external physical fields such as electric field, electromagnetic field and ultrasonic field were always introduced during the preparation of the particle reinforced aluminum matrix composites [8-10].
High-energy ultrasonic has considered as a promising technology in metallurgical industry to
degas, clean the metallic melt and refine the final metallic structures [11-13]. At the same time, researchers have also found that the ultrasonic can disperse micron-sized particles effectively and

improve the yield of the reinforcements, due to its nonlinear effects of cavitation, acoustic streaming, and radiation pressure in the melt [14-17]. Tsunekawa et al. prepared SiO2/Al-Mg composites by ultrasonic vibration and found that the high-energy ultrasonic can improve the wettability between the reinforcements and the metal matrix, and promote the chemical reaction during the synthesis of the composites [14]. Liu et al. used the high-intensity ultrasonic vibration to disperse Al3Ti particles into the matrix melt and degas the melt as well [15, 17]. However, most of the researches in the literatures focused on the effects of high-energy ultrasonic vibration on the dispersion of micro-sized reinforcement particles, and little work was reported about the effect of high-energy ultrasonic vibration on the distribution of nano-sized reinforcements and the porosity in the aluminum composites.
In this work, the ultrasonic vibration was used in the fabrication of in situ nano ZrB2/2024Al
composites from 2024Al-k2ZrF6-KBF4 system by direct melt reaction method. And the effects of ultrasound vibration on the clusters of the in situ nano ZrB2 particles, the porosity, as well as the tensile properties of the composites were further investigated. 2 Experimental

Fig. 1 shows the schematic illustration of the experimental apparatus for the fabrication of the
in situ nano ZrB2/2024Al composite under ultrasonic field. And the in situ 10 vol.% nano ZrB2/2024Al composite was synthesized by the reaction between the molten 2024Al alloy and the K2ZrF6-KBF4 mixed inorganic salts at 870 oC, based on the total reaction shown as formula 1 and the thermodynamic condition of Al–K2ZrF6–KBF4 system [6]. Table 1 gives the composition of the 2024Al alloy. And the inorganic salts are industry reagents with purity over 99.5% and with

particle size of about 100 µm. In order to ensure the reaction completed, the mole ratio of the added K2ZrF6 and KBF4 salts is 1:1.25, a 20% excess of KBF4 powder, due to easy burning loss of B element in molten aluminum [6, 7]. When the mixed salts were added to the molten 2024Al (500 g molten alloy in this study), an electromagnetic stirrer (DJMR-1616 W) was utilized to increase the mass transfer and with reaction time of about 30 min, thus the Zr and B elements of the inorganic salts could be absorbed and formed ZrB2 reinforcements via spontaneous in situ reaction, while the liquid by-products of KAlF4 and K3AlF6 were kept on the top layer of aluminum melt. After the removing of the by-products as slags, the composite melt was degassed and refined using C2Cl6 at 750 oC, and then introduced ultrasonic field with power and frequency of 1.2 kW and 20 kHz, respectively. In particular, after the ultrasonic processing with different time, a portion of high-temperature composite melt close to ultrasonic probe bottom was extracted using a quartz tube (7 mm in diameter) and then cooled in water. These obtained samples are named as as-extracted samples and used to estimate the influence of the time of ultrasonic processing. And after the ultrasonic processing, the composite melt was quickly poured into a water-cooling copper module at 710~720 oC and cooled to the room temperature. Finally, all the composite samples were subjected to the treatment of solution at 500 oC for 30 min for the microstructure observation and aging at 180 oC for 10 h for the mechanical tests of the composites (T6 state).
X-ray diffraction (DMAX2500PC) using Cu Kα radiation was used to determine the phase
components of the specimens. SEM (JSM-7001F) was used to analyze the microstructure of the as-prepared specimens. TEM (JSM2010) was used to observe the morphologies and the interfaces between the matrix and in situ reinforcements. Tensile test of the specimens were carried out at

room temperature on a computer-controlled electronic tensile testing machine (Instron-2366) with a strain rate of 1.67×10-4 s-1 according to the ASTM E8 standard. And the size of the tensile specimens is shown in Fig. 2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1. Microstructure characteristics of the composites
XRD patterns of the fabricated 10 vol.% ZrB2/2024Al composites are shown in Fig. 3. It can
be seen that only Al, CuAl2 and ZrB2 phases are detected in the range of 20-80° for both the composites with and without high-energy ultrasonic treatment. Therefore, the ZrB2 was established to the only reinforcement in the composites fabricated from 2024Al-k2ZrF6-KBF4 system in this study. At the same time, it can also be seen that the composite fabricated with high-energy ultrasonic vibration exhibits a higher peak intensity of the ZrB2 phase, shown in Fig. 3. And this phenomenon should be related to the yield improvement or uniformity improvement of the reinforcement phase, which could be seen from the analysis of the microstructure observation of the composites.
The SEM microstructures of the in situ ZrB2/2024Al composite (solution state) fabricated
with the assistance of high-energy ultrasonic vibration are shown in Fig. 4a. It can be seen that there are many white particles with size from 200 nm to 600 nm observed in the composites. At the same time, there are still many nanoparticles around the large particles. The EDS spectrum in Fig. 4b demonstrates the existence of Al, Zr and B elements and indicates that the white particles should be ZrB2 reinforcements combining with the XRD analysis in Fig. 3. Fig. 5 shows the TEM morphology of the in situ particles in the aluminum matrix. As shown in Fig. 5a, it can be seen that there are lots of in situ synthesized particles in the matrix, and some of particles agglomerate

and exhibit as black blocks with size of about 500 nm. Fig. 5b is the magnification of the area marked in Fig. 5a and shows the uniform-distributed nanoparticles in the matrix. Fig. 5c is the magnified TEM image of the black-blocked area, marked in Fig. 5a. It is obvious that the black area is composed of a mass of nanoparticles, and both the uninform-distributed particles and the agglomerated particles in the black blocks are all in size of about 10-30 nm, where the calibration result of the diffraction ring of the marked nanoparticles, shown as the inset in Fig. 5c, indicates that the nanoparticles are ZrB2. Fig. 5d gives the high resolution electron microscopy image of the in situ nano ZrB2 reinforcements in the fabricated ZrB2/2024 aluminum composites and indicates that the interface of the matrix and the reinforcement exhibits a good interatomic bonding. 3.2 Microstructure evolution of the composites treated with ultrasonic field 3.2.1 Evolution of the clusters of in situ ZrB2 nanoparticles
Assuming that the rapid cooling can well reflect the microstructure of the composite melt,
these as-extracted samples can be used to evaluate the distribution of the in situ ZrB2 nanoparticles in the composites melt. And the evolution of the clusters of ZrB2 particles in the sample treated by high-energy ultrasonic vibration with different processing time is shown in Fig. 6 by the SEM examination. It can be seen that the ZrB2 nanoparticles were easily to agglomerate together and form clusters due to their high interfacial energy in the aluminum melt by simple mechanical stirring, as shown in Fig. 6a. However, with the introduction of ultrasonic vibration, the ZrB2 clusters could be broken and the size of the clusters decreased obviously (Fig. 6 a-d). As shown in Fig. 6b, some cracks could be seen in the large size clusters (after 1 min treatment) and indicate that the high-energy ultrasonic vibration is able to break the particle clusters. And with the ultrasonic treatment time increased, the size of the clusters decreased, as shown in Fig. 6c and d.

In particular, we could find that a number of very fine particle clusters distributed in the matrix uniformly. However, as shown in Fig. 6e and f, the size of the particle clusters could became coarse again, when the sonication time was more than 5 min. 3.2.2 Evolution of the porosity in the composites
As we all know that the porosity must be avoided, due to these defects can be highly
detrimental to the mechanical properties of the materials. Usually, the occurrence of porosity is attributed to the absorbed hydrogen gas during the smelting of the alloy and the drawn oxide formed on the melt surface, especially for the composite melts which are always prepared with mechanical or electromagnetic stirring [18, 19]. In our experiment, some irregular pores were observed in the sample without ultrasonic treatment (Fig. 6a), and some ZrB2 particles agglomerated in these pores, which did not bond with aluminum matrix sufficiently. And this occurrence of the above agglomerated nanoparticles with pores could be analyzed form the solidification of the composite melt. During the solidification of aluminum composite melt, a network of alpha-aluminum dendrites is developed, firstly. Thus, the in situ synthesized nano reinforcements have a great tendency to be pushed towards the solidification front, i.e., the grain boundary of the matrix. And the pinning effects of the ZrB2 nanoparticles at the grain boundaries could suppress the grain growth. Meanwhile, the accumulation of hydrogen gas was generated in a pocket of interdendritic liquid, due to the decrease of solubility of hydrogen gas with the solidification of the melt. However, with the introduction of ultrasonic vibration, there are no or few pores observed in the final composites shown in Fig. 6b-f. 3.2.3 Mechanisms of the high-energy ultrasonic vibration
The disruption of the in situ synthesized nano ZrB2 clusters should be attributed to the

alternating shear stress induced by the high-energy ultrasonic vibration in the melt. On the one hand, the injection of the ultrasonic vibration in the liquid gives rise to nonlinear effects, such as cavitation and acoustic streaming. And the cavitation effects of the high-power ultrasonic vibration are risen form the expanding-clogging-bursting dynamics processing, which produces instantaneous local high-temperature, press and high-intensity shock waves in the fluid and generates ultrasonic bubbles. According to the literature of Ref. [21], the relationship between the velocity of maximum bubble wall and the radius of cavitation bubble in the process of acoustic cavitation bubble insulation meet [22]:

This high instantaneous press and temperature produced in the ultrasonic field are really benefit to the disruption of the clusters of ZrB2 particles. On the other hand, when the high-energy ultrasonic vibration is transmitted in the aluminum melt, the sonic-press gradients are built from the sonic source due to the finite amplitude attenuation with the interaction of the sound wave and the viscous force of the aluminum melt [23]. These sonic-press gradients are contributed to the flowing of the melt, and the circulation flow of the aluminum melt. All of these induce the acoustic streaming effects of vibration and stirring.
A schematic diagram was shown in Fig. 7 to illustrate the mechanism of the disruption of the
large size clusters in the high-energy ultrasonic field. As shown in Fig. 7a, the injection of high-energy ultrasonic field in the molten metal gave rise to nonlinear effects, such as cavitation and a mixed flow consisted of horizontally turning and vertically cycle. As the processing time increased, some large clusters of ZrB2 were sheared into smaller clusters by the shock waves, which created from the collapse of the cavitation, as shown in Fig. 7b. With the time increasing, more and more large clusters of ZrB2 flow into reaction zone and are sheared into smaller clusters by the shock waves (Fig. 7c). As a result, much more fine and uniform particle cluster distribution has been reached in the composite, as shown in Fig. 7d. However, the cavitation effects can also increase the surface activity and the inter-particle collision of the particles, i.e., providing the impetus of the particle agglomeration. And the dispersed particles may agglomerate and settle again. The coarse clusters in Fig. 6e and f. indicate that with the ultrasonic time prolonged (> 5min), the fine ZrB2 tend to cluster again.
The mechanism of the ultrasonic degassing is intimately related to the phenomenon of
cavitation produced by ultrasonic vibration in the melt. In general, ultrasonic degassing can be
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
10
divided into three stages: (1) nucleation of cavitation bubbles on nuclei and growth of the bubbles due to the transformation of gases from the surrounding melt to the bubbles, (2) coalescence of bubbles to form large bubbles, and (3) float of large bubbles to the surface of the molten metal and escape the bubbles at the top melt surface [24].
In our research, the cavitation was generated and mainly formed near the tip of ultrasonic
radiator in the melt when the high-energy ultrasonic vibration was injected in the aluminum composite melt. Meanwhile, the cavitation bubbles were transported into the melt horizontally and vertically. And the gases inside the composite melt could be directly captured by these cavitation bubbles. As a result, with the crush of the ZrB2 clusters broken up by the high-energy ultrasonic vibration, the gases in the clusters can be quickly captured by cavitation bubble and float to the surface of the melt, which gave rise to the degassing of the composites. As a result, the porosity in the composites could be decreased obviously with the sonication time increased. 3.3. Tensile behavior and strengthening mechanisms
The tensile properties of the 10 vol.% ZrB2/2024Al composites treated with sonication times
of 0, 1, 3, 5, 7 and 9 min during the fabrication are listed in table 2, according to the tensile stress-strain curves of the corresponding composites shown as Fig 8. It can be easily seen that the tensile properties of the composites are enhanced first and then decreased with the sonication time increase. And it should be noted that when the processing time is 5 min, the fabricated composites exhibit a maximum mechanical properties with tensile strength, yield stress and elongation of 296 MPa, 182 MPa and 19.2% respectively, about 1.21, 1.77 and 1.10 times of the composites without ultrasonic processing.
It is well known that the Orowan strengthening, load transmitting and grain refinement
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
11
strengthening are the main strengthening mechanisms of the nanoparticle reinforced aluminum matrix composites. In this work, when the ultrasonic field is applied, the uniformity of the nano ZrB2 particles is improved and results in dislocation propagation and tangle in the final composites during deformation. In addition, with the uniformity improvement of the nanoparticle distribution, the stress could be transferred effectively from the matrix to the particulates and the particulates to the matrix well. Meanwhile, the in situ particles of ZrB2 have been proved to possess a significant heterogeneous nucleation effects for the aluminum and its alloys [24-25]. And the uniform distribution of the in situ ZrB2 is beneficial for the grain refinement of the matrix grains during the solidification of the melt, as shown in Fig. 9, i.e., the more the uniformity of the in situ ZrB2 is, the smaller the matrix grains are, and results in improvement in both strength and elongation of the composite, simultaneously. Thus, with the introduction of the ultrasonic vibration, the uniformity of the in situ nanoparticles was improved and the mechanical property of the composites was enhanced. However, the longtime of ultrasonic vibration can lead to the agglomeration and coarsen of the nanoparticles, and results in mechanical property decrease of the composites. 4 Conclusions
High-energy ultrasonic vibration was employed to achieve the uniform distribution of the in
situ synthesized ZrB2 nanoparticles in the nano ZrB2/2024Al composites during fabrication. And the effects of ultrasonic vibration on the nanoparticle distribution, porosity and mechanical properties of the in situ nanocomposites were further studied. The results show that the large clusters of the agglomerated in situ nanoparticles could be broken up into smaller ones and/or uniformly distributed in the matrix by the nonlinear effects, such as cavitation and acoustic streaming, arising from the high-energy ultrasonic vibration. At the same time, the ultrasonic
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
12
treatment also has a significant degassing effect and results in fewer defects and mechanical property enhancement of the nanocomposites. When the processing time of the ultrasonic vibration was 5 min with 1.2 kW in power and 20 kHz in frequency, the fabricated composite exhibits a relatively uniform distribution of ZrB2 nanoparticles, few defects in the matrix and high mechanical performance among the fabricated specimens. And the 10 vol.% nano ZrB2/2024Al composites with ultrasonic processing time of 5 min in the composite melt during the fabrication exhibits tensile strength, yield stress and elongation of 296 MPa, 182 MPa and 19.2% respectively, about 1.21, 1.77 and 1.10 times of the composites without ultrasonic processing, respectively.
